blocks.content: Session hijacking means stealing or taking over a user's active session on a website or application. In naval style, it is like secretly taking control of a ship's communication channel while the ship believes it is still talking to its own base.

content: Attacker steals the user session ID
Attacker uses the session to act as the victim
Attacker can access accounts without knowing passwords

blocks.content: Websites give each user a session ID after login. If an attacker steals that ID, they can log in as the user. This is like copying a ship's secret access code and entering restricted naval zones freely.

content: If cookie is stolen, session is stolen
Sniffing – Capturing cookies over unencrypted networks
MITM – Sitting between user and server
XSS – Stealing cookies using malicious scripts
Session Fixation – Forcing a victim to use a known session ID
Attacker can perform actions as the user
No password is required once the session is stolen
Victim does not know they were hacked
